title: BLOODLINE

embed.description: Taliyah had almost forgotten how much she'd missed the furnace heat of Shurima - the sweat and crush of hundreds of people pushing, cursing, haggling and speaking with such passion and speed that outsiders often thought they were fighting. In all her travels, she'd never found anywhere with the sheer bustle and energy of her homeland.

body: Read on dear lore fans! A twelve section story!

Alright, done reading it now.

It was really good.  I thought there was a bit much of the "made up words to make the setting unique" trope towards the beginning, but it settles down and it gets far better in that department.  The characters were great, the flow felt really good despite changing viewpoints, which is tricky to do in a story like this, where everything is happening so quickly.  I enjoyed the hell out of it.

Taliyah's a better character than I thought she was.  I don't like her ingame VO too much, she felt kinda generic, but her character is very well portrayed here, she's got an almost Braum-level compassion to her, and she stood up to the giant Jackal man.

Sivir, again, bores me in game, but she was great in this.  Clearly getting stabbed has taken away zero of her snark, which is fantastic.

Nasus is one of my favorite League characters, and this was a different sort of characterization than I was used to.  Nasus is usually so serene, but when the shit hits the fan, he can clearly be a force of nature.  And I really liked seeing that.  I also love that he's basically an old man grumbling to himself about these whippersnappers and how they can't respect the good ol' Shurimas.

I think we can erase any doubts about Xerath having remorse.  He's in full on "cackle as I lob meteors into a town" mode, Veigar would be proud.  Still, the descriptions of his powers and the way he moves, being...a sarcophagus and all, were just top notch.  I've written a story with Xerath in it and I kinda struggled to go beyond "uh he shoots blue lightning at a dude????", but this was really good, and made him READ like the demigod wizard he is in Lore.

Overall, my only two real complaints are that it didn't really drop us any big new plot elements like Burning Tides did, (Yeah, Nasus and Renekton are going to fight, Xerath is a bastard, we knew that.), and that it looks like there won't be a sequel.  At least for a while.  Still, I loved it, and I'm looking forward to whatever comes up next.

The whole story is awesome, but this little tidbit goes a long way in illustrating how important family is for Shurimans.

Most of it was fine. I still dislike how Xerath is being treated; Jaredan can say that he isn't meant to be fully evil all he wants, Xerath is going full evil overlord right now.

>Fiery winds carried Xerath’s spiteful laughter, an ageless insanity that reveled in the pain of others.

Xerath went full evil overlord NPC. The sentences used to describe his deeds are completely targeted at stirring up hatred for him in the reader; what the story looks like from Xerath's point of view doesn't matter. What matters is how the readers see him. I remember his quote from the Old Lore where he said that he has no need for vengeance because at the end, only he will remain. To go from that to reveling in inflicting pain to others and becoming a slavemaster even though he was a slave, draws out a sad sigh from me.

If at least the the tiny detail of the plot twist during the Ascension was different, he wouldn't have been portrayed in such a negative light - the detail which says that Xerath decided to go through with the plan even though Azir freed him and his people. It's not implied that Xerath could not stop the sabotage.

It was stated in an earlier draft of the ascension story that they shared on the boards at the time of the first shurima event. I'm slightly miffed that they've decided to remove it from the final version.

That said, Xerath does seem to be about to kill Nasus, and then Nasus' words making him decide not to. He may not admit that Nasus' words had any effect; he may stick to his story about how he wants to see Renekton kill Nasus; but I wonder if part of it is a tiny piece of humanity hidden deep inside him.

I am not *completely* sure of that.

The symbolism of the piece is quite interesting, with Nasus obssesing over how the present-day Shurimans can ony build shoddy imitations of the old glorious days, and Xerath going all Dresden on Vekaura plus personally killing that priest dude. They are still fighting the conflict that was born on old Shurima: Nasus a protector of the empire, and Xerath doing his best to undo it.

Also worth noting: Nasus wielding *slave* as a slur against Xerath. The Curator of the Sands is supposedly one of the wisest people of Ancient Shurima, yet he enjoys telling Xerath that being chattel is on the same ballpark as being a traitor. Xerath is not the only monster among the Ascended.
